THE FATAL PASSION.</br>Now why must I disturb a dream of bliss,</br>Or bring cold sorrow 'twixt the wedded kiss?</br>Sad is the strain, with which I cheer my long</br>And caged hours, and try my native tongue;</br>Now too, while rains autumnal, as I sing,</br>Wash the dull bars, chilling my sicklied wing,</br>And all the climate presses on my sense;</br>But thoughts it furnishes of things far hence,</br>And leafy dreams affords me, and a feeling</br>Which I should else disdain, tear-dipped and healing;</br>And shews me, — more than what it first designed,—</br>How little upon earth our home we find,</br>Or close the intended course of erring human-kind.

Enough of this.  Yet how shall I disclose</br>The weeping days that with the morning rose,</br>How bring the bitter disappointment in,—</br>The holy cheat, the virtue-binding sin,—</br>The shock, that told this lovely, trusting heart,</br>That she had given, beyond all power to part,</br>Her hope, belief, love, passion, to one brother,</br>Possession (oh, the misery!) to another!

Some likeness was there 'twixt the two, — an air</br>At times, a cheek, a colour of the hair,</br>A tone, when speaking of indifferent things;</br>Nor, by the scale of common measurings,</br>Would you say more perhaps, than that the one</br>Was more robust, the other finelier spun;</br>That of the two, Giovanni was the graver,</br>Paulo the livelier, and the more in favour.

Pride in his warlike fame made some prefer</br>Giovanni's countenance as the martialler;</br>And 'twas a soldier's truly, if an eye</br>Ardent and cool at once, drawn-back and high,</br>An eagle's nose and a determined lip,</br>Were the best marks of manly soldiership.</br>Paulo's was fashioned in a different mould,</br>And finer still, I think; for though 'twas bold,</br>When boldness was required, and could put on</br>A glowing frown as if an angel shone,</br>Yet there was nothing in it one might call</br>A stamp exclusive or professional,—</br>No courtier's face, and yet its smile was ready,—</br>No scholar's, yet its look was deep and steady,—</br>No soldier's, for its power was all of mind,</br>Too true for violence, and too refined.</br>A graceful nose was his, lightsomely brought</br>Down from a forehead of clear-spirited thought;</br>Wisdom looked sweet and inward from his eye;</br>And round his mouth was sensibility:—</br>It was a face, in short, seemed made to shew</br>How far the genuine flesh and blood could go;—</br>A morning glass of unaffected nature,—</br>Something, that baffled every pompous feature,—</br>The visage of a glorious human creature.

If any points there were, at which they came</br>Nearer together, 'twas in knightly fame,</br>And all accomplishments that art might know,—</br>Hunting, and princely hawking, and the bow,</br>The rush together in the bright-eyed list,</br>Fore-thoughted chess, the riddle rarely missed,</br>And the decision of still knottier points,</br>With knife in hand, of boar and peacock joints,—</br>Things, that might shake the fame that Tristan got,</br>And bring a doubt on perfect Launcelot.</br>But leave we knighthood to the former part;</br>The tale I tell is of the human heart.

The worst of Prince Giovanni, as his bride</br>Too quickly found, was an ill-tempered pride.</br>Bold, handsome, able if he chose to please,</br>Punctual and right in common offices,</br>He lost the sight of conduct's only worth,</br>The scattering smiles on this uneasy earth,</br>And on the strength of virtues of small weight,</br>Claimed tow'rds himself the exercise of great.</br>He kept no reckoning with his sweets and sours;—</br>He'd hold a sullen countenance for hours,</br>And then, if pleased to cheer himself a space,</br>Look for the immediate rapture in your face,</br>And wonder that a cloud could still be there,</br>How small soever, when his own was fair.</br>Yet such is conscience, — so designed to keep</br>Stern, central watch, though all things else may sleep,</br>And so much knowledge of one's self there lies</br>Cored, after all, in our complacencies,</br>That no suspicion would have touched him more,</br>Than that of wanting on the generous score:</br>He would have whelmed you with a weight of scorn,</br>Been proud at eve, inflexible at morn,</br>In short, ill-tempered for a week to come,</br>And all to strike that desperate error dumb.</br>Taste had he, in a word, for high-turned merit,</br>But not the patience, nor the genial spirit;</br>And so he made, 'twixt virtue and defect,</br>A sort of fierce demand on your respect,</br>Which, if assisted by his high degree,</br>It gave him in some eyes a dignity,</br>And struck a meaner deference in the many,</br>Left him, at last, unloveable with any.

From this complexion in the reigning brother,</br>His younger birth in part had saved the other.</br>Born to a homage less gratuitous,</br>He learned to win a nobler for his house;</br>And both from habit and a genial heart,</br>Without much trouble of the reasoning art,</br>Found this the wisdom and the sovereign good,—</br>To be, and make, as happy as he could.</br>Not that he saw, or thought he saw, beyond</br>His general age, and could not be as fond</br>Of wars and creeds as any of his race,—</br>But most he loved a happy human face;</br>And wheresoe'er his fine, frank eyes were thrown,</br>He struck the looks he wished for with his own.</br>His danger was, lest, feeling as he did,</br>Too lightly he might leap o'er means forbid.</br>And in some tempting hour lose sight of crime</br>O'er some sweet face too happy for the time;</br>But fears like these he never entertained,</br>And had they crossed him, would have been disdained.</br>Warm was his youth, 'tis true, — nor had been free</br>From lighter loves, — but virtue reverenced he,</br>And had been kept from men of pleasure's cares</br>By dint of feelings still more warm than theirs.</br>So what but service leaped where'er he went!</br>Was there a tilt-day or a tournament,—</br>For welcome grace there rode not such another,</br>Nor yet for strength, except his lordly brother,</br>Was there a court-day, or a sparkling feast</br>Or better still, — in my ideas, at least,—</br>A summer party to the greenwood shade,</br>With lutes prepared, and cloth on herbage laid,</br>And ladies' laughter coming through the air,—</br>He was the readiest and the blithest there;</br>And made the time so exquisitely pass</br>With stories told with elbow on the grass,</br>Or touched the music in his turn so finely,</br>That all he did, they thought, was done divinely.

The lovely stranger could not fail to see</br>Too soon this difference, more especially</br>As her consent, too lightly now, she thought,</br>With hopes as different had been strangely bought;</br>And many a time the pain of that neglect</br>Would strike in blushes o'er her self-respect:</br>But since the ill was cureless, she applied</br>With busy virtue to resume her pride,</br>Hoping to value her submissive heart</br>On playing well a patriot daughter's part,</br>And trying new-found duties to prefer</br>To what a father might have owed to her.</br>The very day too when her first surprise</br>Was full, kind tears had come into her eyes</br>On finding, by his care, her private room</br>Furnished, like magic, from her own at home;</br>The very books and all transported there,</br>The leafy tapestry, and the crimson chair,</br>The lute, the glass that told the shedding hours,</br>The little vase of silver for the flowers,</br>The frame for broidering, with a piece half done,</br>And the white falcon, basking in the sun,</br>Who, when he saw her, sidled on his stand,</br>And twined his neck against her loving hand.</br>But what had touched her nearest, was the thought,</br>That if 'twere destined for her to be brought</br>To a sweet mother's bed, the joy would be</br>Giovanni's too, and his her family:—</br>He seemed already father of her child,</br>And on the nestling pledge in patient thought she smiled.</br>Yet then a pang would cross her, and the red</br>In either downward cheek startle and spread,</br>To think that he, who was to have such part</br>In joys like these, had never shared her heart;</br>But back she chased it with a sigh austere;</br>And did she chance, at times like these, to hear</br>Her husband's footstep, she would haste the more,</br>And with a double smile open the door,</br>And hope his day had worn a happy face;</br>Ask how his soldiers pleased him in reviewing,</br>Or if the boar was slain, which he had been pursuing.

The prince, at this, would bend on her an eye</br>Cordial enough, and kiss her tenderly;</br>Nor, to say truth, was he slow in common</br>To accept the attentions of this lovely woman;</br>But then meantime he took no generous pains,</br>By mutual pleasing, to secure his gains;</br>He entered not, in turn, in her delights,</br>Her books, her flowers, her taste for rural sights;</br>Nay, scarcely her sweet singing minded he,</br>Unless his pride was roused by company;</br>Or when to please him, after martial play,</br>She strain'd her lute to some old fiery lay</br>Of fierce Orlando, or of Ferumbras,</br>Or Ryan's cloak, or how by the red grass</br>In battle you might know where Richard was.

Yet all the while, no doubt, however stern</br>Or cold at times, he thought he loved in turn,</br>And that the joy he took in her sweet ways,</br>The pride he felt when she excited praise,</br>In short, the enjoyment of his own good pleasure,</br>Was thanks enough, and passion beyond measure.

She, had she loved him, might have thought so too,</br>For what will love's exalting not go through,</br>Till long neglect, and utter selfishness,</br>Shame the fond pride it takes in its distress?</br>But ill prepared was she, in her hard lot,</br>To fancy merit where she found it not,—</br>She, who had been beguil'd, — she, who was made</br>Within a gentle bosom to be laid,—</br>To bless and to be blessed, — to be heart-bare</br>To one who found his bettered likeness there,—</br>To think for ever with him, like a bride,—</br>To haunt his eye, like grace personified,—</br>To double his delight, to share his sorrow,</br>And like a morning beam, wake to him every morrow.

Paulo, meantime, who ever since the day</br>He saw her sweet looks bending o'er his way,</br>Had stored them up, unconsciously, as graces</br>By which to judge all other forms and faces,</br>Had learnt, I know not how, the secret snare,</br>Which gave her up, that evening, to his care.</br>Some babbler, may-be, of old Guido's court,</br>Or foolish friend had told him, half in sport:</br>But to his heart the fatal flattery went,</br>And grave he grew, and inwardly intent,</br>And ran back, in his mind, with sudden spring,</br>Look, gesture, smile, speech, silence, every thing,</br>Even what before had seemed indifference,</br>And read them over in another sense.</br>Then would he blush with sudden self-disdain,</br>To think how fanciful he was, and vain;</br>And with half angry, half regretful sigh,</br>Tossing his chin, and feigning a free eye,</br>Breathe off, as 'twere, the idle tale, and look</br>About him for his falcon or his book,</br>Scorning that ever he should entertain</br>One thought that in the end might give his brother pain.

This start, however, came so often round,—</br>So often fell he in deep thought, and found</br>Occasion to renew his carelessness,</br>Yet every time the power grown less and less,</br>That by degrees, half wearied, half inclined,</br>To the sweet struggling image he resigned;</br>And merely, as he thought, to make the best</br>Of what by force would twine about his breast,</br>Began to bend down his admiring eyes</br>On all her touching looks and qualities,</br>Turning their shapely sweetness every way,</br>Till 'twas his food and habit day by day,</br>And she became companion of his thought;</br>Silence her gentleness before him brought,</br>Society her sense, reading her books,</br>Music her voice, every sweet thing her looks,</br>Which sometimes seemed, when he sat fixed awhile,</br>To steal beneath his eyes with upward smile:</br>And did he stroll into some lonely place,</br>Under his trees, upon the thick soft grass,</br>How charming, would he think, to see her here!</br>How heightening then, and perfect would appear</br>The two divinest things this world has got,</br>A lovely woman in a rural spot!

Thus daily went he on, gathering sweet pain</br>About his fancy, till it thrilled again;</br>And if his brother's image, less and less,</br>Startled him up from his new idleness,</br>'Twas not, — he fancied, — that he reason'd worse,</br>Or felt less scorn of wrong, but the reverse.</br>That one should think of injuring another,</br>Or trenching on his peace, — this too a brother,—</br>And all from selfishness and pure weak will,</br>To him seemed marvellous and impossible.</br>'Tis true, thought he, one being more there was,</br>Who might meantime have weary hours to pass,—</br>One weaker too to bear them, — and for whom?—</br>No matter; — wishing could reverse no doom;</br>And so he sighed and smiled, as if one thought</br>Of paltering could suppose that he was to be caught.

Yet if she lov'd him, common gratitude,</br>If not, a sense of what was fair and good,</br>Besides his new relationship and right,</br>Would make him wish to please her all he might;</br>And as to thinking, — where could be the harm,</br>Provided he kept close the secret charm?</br>He wished not to himself another's blessing,</br>But then he might console for not possessing;</br>And glorious things there were, which but to see</br>And not admire, was mere stupidity:</br>He might as well object to his own eyes</br>For loving to behold the fields and skies,</br>His neighbour's grove, or story-painted hall;</br>'Twas but the taste for what was natural;</br>Only his fav'rite thought was loveliest of them all.

Concluding thus, and happier that he knew</br>His ground so well, near and more near he drew;</br>And sanction'd by his brother's manner, spent</br>Hours by her side, as happy as well-meant.</br>He read with her, he rode, he went a hawking,</br>He spent still evenings in delightful talking,</br>While she sat busy at her broidery frame;</br>Or touched the lute with her, and when they came</br>To some fine part, prepared her for the pleasure,</br>And then with double smile stole on the measure.

Then at the tournament, — who there but she</br>Made him more gallant still than formerly,</br>Couch o'er his tightened lance with double force,</br>Pass like the wind, sweeping down man and horse,</br>And franklier then than ever, midst the shout</br>And dancing trumpets ride, uncovered, round about?</br>His brother only, more than hitherto,</br>He would avoid, or sooner let subdue,</br>Partly from something strange unfelt before,</br>Partly because Giovanni sometimes wore</br>A knot his bride had worked him, green and gold;—</br>For in all things with nature did she hold;</br>And while 'twas being worked, her fancy was</br>Of sunbeams mingling with a tuft of grass.

Francesca from herself but ill could hide</br>What pleasure now was added to her side,—</br>How placidly, yet fast, the days succeeded</br>With one who thought and felt so much as she did,—</br>And how the chair he sat in, and the room,</br>Began to look, when he had failed to come.</br>But as she better knew the cause than he,</br>She seemed to have the more necessity</br>For struggling hard, and rousing all her pride;</br>And so she did at first; she even tried</br>To feel a sort of anger at his care;</br>But these extremes brought but a kind despair;</br>And then she only spoke more sweetly to him,</br>And found her failing eyes give looks that melted through him.

Giovanni too, who felt relieved indeed</br>To see another to his place succeed,</br>Or rather filling up some trifling hours,</br>Better spent elsewhere, and beneath his powers,</br>Left the new tie to strengthen day by day,</br>Talked less and less, and longer kept away,</br>Secure in his self-love and sense of right,</br>That he was welcome most, come when he might.</br>And doubtless, they, in their still finer sense,</br>With added care repaid this confidence,</br>Turning their thoughts from his abuse of it,</br>To what on their own parts was graceful and was fit.

Ah now, ye gentle pair, — now think awhile,</br>Now, while ye still can think, and still can smile;</br>Now, while your generous hearts have not been grieved</br>Perhaps with something not to be retrieved,</br>And ye have in ye still the power of gladness,</br>From self-resentment free, and recollected madness!

So did they think; — but partly from delay,</br>Partly from fancied ignorance of the way,</br>But most from feeling the bare contemplation</br>Give them fresh need of mutual consolation,</br>They scarcely tried to see each other less,</br>And did but meet with deeper tenderness,</br>Living, from day to day, as they were used,</br>Only with graver thoughts, and smiles reduced,</br>And sighs more frequent, which, when one would heave,</br>The other longed to start up and receive.</br>For whether some suspicion now had crossed</br>Giovanni's mind, or whether he had lost</br>More of his temper lately, he would treat</br>His wife with petty scorns, and starts of heat,</br>And, to his own omissions proudly blind,</br>O'erlook the pains she took to make him kind,</br>And yet be angry, if he thought them less;</br>He found reproaches in her meek distress,</br>Forcing her silent tears, and then resenting,</br>Then almost angrier grown from half repenting,</br>And hinting at the last, that some there were</br>Better perhaps than he, and tastefuller,</br>And these, for what he knew, — he little cared,—</br>Might please her, and be pleased, though he despaired.</br>Then would he quit the room, and half disdain</br>His tongue for yielding to so harsh a strain,</br>And venting thus his temper on a woman;</br>Yet not the more for that changed he in common,</br>Or took more pains to please her, and be near:—</br>What!  should he truckle to a woman's tear?

At times like these the princess tried to shun</br>The face of Paulo as too kind a one;</br>And shutting up her tears with final sigh,</br>Would walk into the air, and see the sky,</br>And feel about her all the garden green,</br>And hear the birds that shot the covert boughs between.

A noble range it was, of many a rood,</br>Walled round with trees, and ending in a wood:</br>Indeed the whole was leafy; and it had</br>A winding stream about it, clear and glad,</br>That danced from shade to shade, and on its way</br>Seemed smiling with delight to feel the day.</br>There was the pouting rose, both red and white,</br>The flamy heart's-ease, flushed with purple light,</br>Blush-hiding strawberry, sunny-coloured box,</br>Hyacinth, handsome with his clustering locks,</br>The lady lily, looking gently down,</br>Pure lavender, to lay in bridal gown,</br>The daisy, lovely on both sides, — in short,</br>All the sweet cups to which the bees resort,</br>With plots of grass, and perfumed walks between</br>Of citron, honeysuckle and jessamine,</br>With orange, whose warm leaves so finely suit,</br>And look as if they'd shade a golden fruit;</br>And midst the flowers, turfed round beneath a shade</br>Of circling pines, a babbling fountain played,</br>And 'twixt their shafts you saw the water bright,</br>Which through the darksome tops glimmered with showering light.</br>So now you walked beside an odorous bed</br>Of gorgeous hues, purple, and gold, and red;</br>And now turned off into a leafy walk,</br>Close and continuous, fit for lovers' talk;</br>And now pursued the stream, and as you trod</br>Onward and onward o'er the velvet sod,</br>Felt on your face an air, watery and sweet,</br>And a new sense in your soft-lighting feet;</br>And then perhaps you entered upon shades,</br>Pillowed with dells and uplands 'twixt the glades,</br>Through which the distant palace, now and then,</br>Looked lordly forth with many-windowed ken</br>A land of trees, which reaching round about,</br>In shady blessing stretched their old arms out,</br>With spots of sunny opening, and with nooks</br>To lie and read in, sloping into brooks,</br>Where at her drink you startled the slim deer,</br>Retreating lightly with a lovely fear.</br>And all about, the birds kept leafy house,</br>And sung and darted in and out the boughs;</br>And all about, a lovely sky of blue</br>Clearly was felt, or down the leaves laughed through;</br>And here and there, in every part, were seats,</br>Some in the open walks, some in retreats</br>With bowering leaves o'erhead, to which the eye</br>Looked up half sweetly and half awfully,—</br>Places of nestling green, for poets made,</br>Where when the sunshine struck a yellow shade,</br>The slender trunks, to inward-peeping sight,</br>Thronged in dark pillars up the gold green light.

But 'twixt the wood and flowery walks, halfway,</br>And formed of both, the loveliest portion lay,</br>A spot, that struck you like enchanted ground:—</br>It was a shallow dell, set in a mound</br>Of sloping shrubs, that mounted by degrees,</br>The birch and poplar mixed with heavier trees;</br>From under which, sent through a marble spout,</br>Betwixt the dark wet green, a rill gushed out,</br>Whose low sweet talking seemed as if it said</br>Something eternal to that happy shade:</br>The ground within was lawn, with plots of flowers</br>Heaped towards the centre, and with citron bowers;</br>And in the midst of all, clustered about</br>With bay and myrtle, and just gleaming out,</br>Lurked a pavilion, — a delicious sight,—</br>Small, marble, well-proportioned, mellowy white,</br>With yellow vine-leaves sprinkled, — but no more,—</br>And a young orange either side the door.</br>The door was to the wood, forward and square,</br>The rest was domed at top, and circular;</br>And through the dome the only light came in,</br>Tinged, as it entered, with the vine-leaves thin.

It was a beauteous piece of ancient skill,</br>Spared from the rage of war, and perfect still;</br>By some supposed the work of fairy hands,</br>Famed for luxurious taste, and choice of lands,—</br>Alcina, or Morgana, — who from fights</br>And errant fame inveigled amorous knights,</br>And lived with them in a long round of blisses,</br>Feasts, concerts, baths, and bower-enshaded kisses.</br>But 'twas a temple, as its sculpture told,</br>Built to the Nymphs that haunted there of old;</br>For o'er the door was carved a sacrifice</br>By girls and shepherds brought, with reverent eyes,</br>Of sylvan drinks and foods, simple and sweet,</br>And goats with struggling horns and planted feet:</br>And on a line with this ran round about</br>A like relief, touched exquisitely out,</br>That shewed, in various scenes, the nymphs themselves;</br>Some by the water side on bowery shelves</br>Leaning at will, — some in the water sporting</br>With sides half swelling forth, and looks of courting,—</br>Some in a flowery dell, hearing a swain</br>Play on his pipe, till the hills ring again,—</br>Some tying up their long moist hair, — some sleeping</br>Under the trees, with fauns and satyrs peeping,—</br>Or, sidelong-eyed, pretending not to see,</br>The latter in the brakes come creepingly,</br>While from their forgotten urns, lying about</br>In the green herbage, let the water out.</br>Never, be sure, before or since was seen</br>A summer-house so fine in such a nest of green.

All the green garden, flower-bed, shade, and plot,</br>Francesca loved, but most of all this spot.</br>Whenever she walked forth, wherever went</br>About the grounds, to this at last she bent:</br>Here she had brought a lute and a few books;</br>Here would she lie for hours, with grateful looks,</br>Thanking at heart the sunshine and the leaves,</br>The vernal rain-drops counting from the eaves,</br>And all that promising, calm smile we see</br>In nature's face, when we look patiently.</br>Then would she think of heaven; and you might hear</br>Sometimes, when every thing was hushed and clear,</br>Her gentle voice from out those shades emerging,</br>Singing the evening anthem to the Virgin.</br>The gardeners and the rest, who served the place,</br>And blest whenever they beheld her face,</br>Knelt when they heard it, bowing and uncovered,</br>And felt as if in air some sainted beauty hovered.

One day, — 'twas on an early autumn noon,</br>When airs and gurgling brooks are best in tune</br>And grasshoppers are loud, and day-work done</br>And shades have heavy outlines in the sun,—</br>The princess came to her accustomed bower</br>To get her, if she could, a soothing hour,</br>Trying, as she was used, to leave her cares</br>Without, and slumberously enjoy the airs,</br>And the low-talking leaves, and that cool light</br>The vines let in, and all that hushing sight</br>Of closing wood seen through the opening door,</br>And distant plash of waters tumbling o'er,</br>And smell of citron blooms, and fifty luxuries more.

She tried, as usual, for the trial's sake,</br>For even that diminished her heart-ache;</br>And never yet, how ill soe'er at ease,</br>Came she for nothing 'midst the flowers and trees.</br>Yet how it was she knew not, but that day,</br>She seemed to feel too lightly borne away,—</br>Too much relieved — too much inclined to draw</br>A careless joy from every thing she saw,</br>And looking round her with a new-born eye,</br>As if some tree of knowledge had been nigh,</br>To taste of nature, primitive and free,</br>And bask at ease in her heart's liberty.

Painfully clear those rising thoughts appeared,</br>With something dark at bottom that she feared;</br>And turning from the trees her thoughtful look,</br>She reached o'er-head, and took her down a book,</br>And fell to reading with as fixed an air,</br>As though she had been wrapt since morning there.

'Twas Launcelot of the Lake, a bright romance,</br>That like a trumpet made young pulses dance,</br>Yet had a softer note that shook still more;—</br>She had begun it but the day before,</br>And read with a full heart, half sweet, half sad,</br>How old King Ban was spoiled of all he had</br>But one fair castle:  how one summer's day</br>With his fair queen and child he went away</br>To ask the great King Arthur for assistance;</br>How reaching by himself a hill at distance</br>He turned to give his castle a last look,</br>And saw its far white face:  and how a smoke,</br>As he was looking, burst in volumes forth,</br>And good King Ban saw all that he was worth,</br>And his fair castle, burning to the ground,</br>So that his wearied pulse felt over-wound,</br>And he lay down, and said a prayer apart</br>For those he loved, and broke his poor old heart.</br>Then read she of the queen with her young child,</br>How she came up, and nearly had gone wild,</br>And how in journeying on in her despair,</br>She reached a lake and met a lady there,</br>Who pitied her, and took the baby sweet</br>Into her arms, when lo, with closing feet</br>She sprang up all at once, like bird from brake,</br>And vanished with him underneath the lake.</br>The mother's feelings we as well may pass:—</br>The fairy of the place that lady was,</br>And Launcelot (so the boy was called) became</br>Her inmate, till in search of knightly fame</br>He went to Arthur's court, and played his part</br>So rarely, and displayed so frank a heart,</br>That what with all his charms of look and limb,</br>The Queen Geneura fell in love with him:—</br>And here, with growing interest in her reading,</br>The princess, doubly fixed, was now proceeding.

Ready she sat with one hand to turn o'er</br>The leaf, to which her thoughts ran on before,</br>The other propping her white brow, and throwing</br>Its ringlets out, under the skylight glowing.</br>So sat she fixed; and so observed was she</br>Of one, who at the door stood tenderly,—</br>Paulo, — who from a window seeing her</br>Go straight across the lawn, and guessing where,</br>Had thought she was in tears, and found, that day,</br>His usual efforts vain to keep away.</br>"May I come in?"  said he: — it made her start,—</br>That smiling voice; — she coloured, pressed her heart</br>A moment, as for breath, and then with free</br>And usual tone said, "O yes, — certainly."

There's wont to be, at conscious times like these,</br>An affectation of a bright-eyed ease,</br>An air of something quite serene and sure,</br>As if to seem so, were to be, secure:</br>With this the lovers met, with this they spoke,</br>With this they sat down to the self-same book,</br>And Paulo, by degrees, gently embraced</br>With one permitted arm her lovely waist;</br>And both their cheeks, like peaches on a tree,</br>Came with a touch together, thrillingly;</br>And o'er the book they hung, and nothing said,</br>And every lingering page grew longer as they read.

As thus they sat, and felt, with leaps of heart,</br>Their colour change, they came upon the part</br>Where fond Geneura, with her flame long nurst,</br>Smiled upon Launcelot when he kiss'd her first:—</br>That touch, at last, through every fibre slid;</br>And Paulo turned, scarce knowing what he did,</br>Only he felt he could no more dissemble,</br>And kissed her, mouth to mouth, all in a tremble.</br>Sad were those hearts, and sweet was that long kiss:</br>Sacred be love from sight, whate'er it is.</br>The world was all forgot, the struggle o'er,</br>Desperate the joy  — That day they read no more.
